awd_titl_txt: Secondary Amine-Containing Organic Micropollutants as Precursors of Previously Uncharacterized N-Nitrosamines in Wastewater
awd_abstract_narration:
Freshwater scarcity is a major challenge both nationally and globally. Many municipalities are considering wastewater reuse as a viable solution to augmenting water supplies to address this issue. One major concern about implementing wastewater reuse stems from the potential public health risks caused by exposure to wastewater-derived pollutants such as N-nitrosamines. Despite this recognition, there remain gaps in our knowledge regarding the formation and prevalence of these compounds. This project will address this gap by investigating the fate and reactivity of precursors that serve as the source of N-nitrosamines in wastewater. Successful completion of this research will benefit water utilities in their ability to monitor N-nitrosamines and assess treatment efficiency of advanced treatment technologies. Regulatory agencies may also find project results useful to assess the risk of N-nitrosamines. This project will provide valuable research training opportunities for underrepresented high school and college students to broaden opportunity and diversify the Nation's STEM workforce. The outreach program will promote direct knowledge transfer to the scientific stakeholder communities, while improving the scientific literacy of the Nation.

N-Nitrosamines are contaminants of potential public health concern for planned and de facto reuse of municipal wastewater effluent. To date, research on N-nitrosamines has focused primarily on N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) and a few other aliphatic or cyclic species. Relatively limited knowledge exists regarding the sources, identities, fate, and risks of uncharacterized N-nitrosamine species. The overall goal of this research project is to address this knowledge gap by 1) examining the yields and formation mechanisms of N-nitroso derivatives upon chloramination of secondary amine-containing pharmaceuticals and pesticides; 2) establishing the relative importance of secondary amine-containing micropollutants as precursors of uncharacterized N-nitrosamines in full-scale wastewater treatment and reuse facilities; and 3) evaluating the impacts of photo- and biotransformation processes on secondary amine-containing micropollutants in wastewater-impacted surface waters. The approach will include both high resolution mass spectrometry and chemiluminescence assays of field samples and bench-scale testing to accomplish the proposed research tasks. An outreach and education plan will seek to broaden participation of underrepresented high school and undergraduate students in environmental research; incorporate research methodologies and outcomes into the environmental curriculum at Syracuse University; and disseminate research results to the broader scientific community, stakeholders, and lay public to improve monitoring and mitigation strategies for N-nitrosamines and their precursors in wastewater.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
N-Nitrosamines are a class of nitrogenous organic contaminants that pose significant public health concerns due to their carcinogenic potential. To date, research in the field of environmental engineering has largely focused on the occurrence, formation, and control of N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) in drinking water, wastewater treatment, and water reuse scenarios. However, NDMA and a few other commonly studied N-nitrosamines constitute only a small fraction of the total N-nitrosamines (TONO) found in source waters and wastewater, with the majority of N-nitrosamines in the TONO pool remaining largely unidentified. Even less is known about the sources and characteristics of precursors to these uncharacterized N-nitrosamines. The overall goal of this research is to address knowledge gaps regarding the composition of total N-nitrosamines in municipal wastewater and their fate during wastewater treatment. The PI developed an integrated experimental setup to compare the performance of two methods for TONO quantification: chemical denitrosation using acidic triiodide treatment and photolytic denitrosation using UV photolysis, both coupled with chemiluminescence detection. With the use of a large-volume purge vessel for chemical denitrosation, the acidic triiodide-based method achieved signal stability and detection limits comparable to those of the UV photolysis-based method, which utilized a microphotochemical reactor that experienced greater matrix interferences when analyzing TONO in wastewater samples. The PI also demonstrated significant variability in the reduction and production of TONO and their precursors across treatment steps at conventional wastewater treatment plants, with some serving as sinks and others as sources, depending on the nature of plant influents and the configurations of secondary and tertiary treatment processes. Lastly, the PI developed a nontarget screening workflow based on liquid chromatography-high-resolution mass spectrometry to prioritize and identify uncharacterized N-nitrosamines, including those formed through N-nitrosation of secondary amine-containing pharmaceuticals, although these newly identified species were only minor components of TONO. Overall, this research has addressed several practical considerations for implementing chemiluminescence methods to quantify TONO, provided new insights into the identities of N-nitrosamines and their precursors beyond those traditionally targeted in water treatment and reuse scenarios, and established a new analytical framework that may have broad applicability in biomedical and agricultural research where N-nitrosamine formation is a concern. This research also provides critical information for water utilities to optimize existing monitoring programs, implement advanced treatment technologies, and improve strategies for risk assessment of N-nitrosamines.


Last Modified: 09/30/2024
Modified by: Teng Zeng
